Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Robotic-Assisted Versus Conventional Total Knee Arthroplasty

Background: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the long-term efficacy of robotic-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to conventional TKA in terms of functional outcomes, radiographic parameters, survivorship, and complications.

Methods: Conducted from January 2002 to February 2008 at a single center, 1406 patients were eligible and randomized to receive robotic-assisted TKA (700 patients, 750 knees) or conventional TKA (706 patients, 766 knees). Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment. Blinding details were not specified. The primary outcome was the Knee Society score, measured preoperatively and at a mean follow-up of 13 years. Sample size calculation assumed a 5-point difference in the Knee Society score with 99% power, requiring 628 patients per group.

Results: At follow-up, 674 patients in each group were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach. No significant differences were observed in Knee Society scores (robotic: 93 ± 5, conventional: 92 ± 6; p = 0.321), WOMAC scores, or UCLA activity scores. Radiographic parameters, including component and limb alignment, were similar between groups. Kaplan-Meier survivorship was 98% in both groups at 15 years. Complications were comparable, with 2% of knees in each group experiencing superficial infections treated with antibiotics. No deep infections were reported, and motion limitation occurred in 0.8% of knees in the conventional group.

Interpretation: Robotic-assisted TKA did not show superior functional outcomes, survivorship, or reduced complications compared to conventional TKA. Considering the additional time and expense, its widespread use is not recommended.
